Course Description: Convex optimization problems constitute an important class of optimization problems for which there is a complete mathematical theory as well as efficient algorithms. As such they have been usefully applied in diverse areas of economics, operations research and engineering. The philosophy behind the course is that an initial investment in structure theory of convex sets and functions yields rich dividends in terms of a better vision of convex (and even non-convex) optimization problems.

Course Outcomes.CO1: Students are able to appreciate the structure theory of convex sets and functions
Course Outcomes.CO2: Students are able to recognize, formulate and solve a convex optimization problem.
Course Outcomes.CO3: Students are able to appreciate and use the duality theory of convex optimization

Weekly Lecture Plan.Lecture Topic: Convex Sets - Affine Sets, Cones, Hyperplanes and Polyhedra
Convexity Preserving Operations; Separating and Supporting Hyperplane Theorems
Convex Functions and Properties; Convexity Preserving Operations
Lagrangian Dual Problem; Strong Duality and Slater’s Constraint Qualification
Geometric and Economic Interpretation of Duality
Complementary Slackness Condition of Optimality; Karush-Kuhn-Tucker Optimality Conditions
Applications- Least Squares Approximation, Linear Classification, Portfolio Choice Model, Principal Agent Model

Resource Material.Textbook: Convex Optimization by Stephen Boyd and Lieven Vanderberghe
Supporting References: Linear Algebra and Its Applications by David Lay, Steven R. Lay and Judi McDonald
Mathematics for Economists by Carl Simon and Lawrence Blume
